body:
Of course. It occurs when you use a `rename_index` with the new "change" method instead of "up/down" in migrations, which is now the default when generating a model for instance.

When you run a `rake db:migrate`, everything's ok since `rename_index` runs in "normal" mode. But when you want to revert your migration with `rake db:rollback` or `rake db:migrate VERSION=0` for instance, the arguments are not in the correct order for the inverted `rename_index`.

Example:

```
% RAILS_ENV=production rake db:create db:migrate db:rollback
[...]
==  RenameIndexOnPostTitle: migrating =========================================
-- rename_index(:posts, "index_on_posts_title", "idx_posts_title")
   -> 0.0954s
==  RenameIndexOnPostTitle: migrated (0.0959s) ================================
==  RenameIndexOnPostTitle: reverting =========================================
-- rename_index("idx_posts_title", "index_on_posts_title", "posts")
rake aborted!
An error has occurred, all later migrations canceled:
Mysql2::Error: Table 'railspr2716.idx_posts_title' doesn't exist: SHOW KEYS FROM `idx_posts_title`
```

If you want to reproduce easily, I created a temporary repository with instructions in the README to see the problem : https://github.com/jbbarth/rails-pull-request-2716

**NB**: the bug is much more visible on mysql than sqlite, because it seems that the sqlite adapter silently fails when a rename index fails.
